quizzes.title: Introduction to Data Communication and Networking - Paper 1

questions.question: What is the main purpose of data communication?
options: To share information between two or more devices
To improve the speed of computing
questions.answer: To share information between two or more devices
questions.explanation: Data communication refers to the process of exchanging information between devices over a communication medium.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of digital data?
questions.explanation: Digital data represents information using binary values (0s and 1s), such as a document, image, or video.

questions.question: Which component is responsible for governing the rules of communication in a data communication system?
questions.explanation: Protocols define the rules for data communication, ensuring devices can exchange information properly.

questions.question: Which type of communication allows data to flow in both directions simultaneously?
questions.explanation: Full-Duplex communication allows simultaneous data transmission and reception between devices.

questions.question: In which type of network do all devices connect to a single communication line?
questions.explanation: In a Bus topology, all devices are connected to a single communication line and share the bandwidth.

questions.question: Which transmission medium uses light to carry data?
questions.explanation: Fiber-optic cables use light signals to transmit data over long distances, providing high-speed communication.

questions.question: What is the term used for a network covering a city?
questions.explanation: A Metropolitan Area Network (MAN) covers a city or metropolitan area.

questions.question: Which of the following network types is designed for personal devices such as smartphones and smartwatches?
questions.explanation: A Personal Area Network (PAN) is used for connecting personal devices like phones, tablets, and wearables.

questions.question: What is the main disadvantage of circuit switching?
questions.explanation: Circuit switching dedicates a communication path for the entire duration of the connection, leading to wasted capacity during idle times.

questions.question: Which of the following is a performance metric used in data communication?
questions.explanation: Throughput refers to the rate at which data is successfully transmitted from sender to receiver.

questions.question: Which type of switching involves dividing data into packets for transmission?
questions.explanation: In packet switching, data is divided into small packets that are transmitted independently across the network.

questions.question: What is the main function of a router in a network?
options: To forward data between devices in the same network
To store data for future use
questions.explanation: Routers are used to connect different networks and forward data between them.

questions.question: Which of the following topologies uses a central hub to manage communication?
questions.explanation: In a Star topology, all devices are connected to a central hub, which manages data communication between devices.

questions.question: What does 'simplex' data flow mean?
options: Data can flow in both directions simultaneously
Data flows only in one direction
Data alternates between transmission and reception
Data flows to multiple receivers at once
questions.answer: Data flows only in one direction
questions.explanation: In simplex communication, data flows only in one direction, such as a keyboard sending input to a computer.

questions.question: What is the role of the transmission medium in a data communication system?
options: It carries the message from sender to receiver
questions.answer: It carries the message from sender to receiver
questions.explanation: The transmission medium is the physical path through which data travels from the sender to the receiver.

questions.question: What is a common example of a simplex device?
questions.explanation: A monitor is a simplex device as it only receives data (output) without sending any data back.

questions.question: Which device is responsible for forwarding data within a small network?
questions.explanation: A switch connects devices within a small network and forwards data between them.

questions.question: Which term refers to a network's geographical size and extent?
questions.explanation: Network extent refers to the geographical size of the network, such as PAN, LAN, MAN, or WAN.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of packet queuing in a network?
options: To buffer packets waiting for transmission
questions.answer: To buffer packets waiting for transmission
questions.explanation: Packet queuing occurs when data arrives faster than it can be transmitted, and packets are buffered until they can be sent.

questions.question: What happens to a packet when it arrives at a full buffer?
options: It is forwarded to another buffer
It is saved for later transmission
questions.explanation: When a buffer is full, any incoming packets are dropped, which may require retransmission.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a protocol in networking?
options: To define the format of data
To govern the communication between devices
questions.answer: To govern the communication between devices
questions.explanation: A protocol is a set of rules that controls the exchange of data between devices in a network.

questions.question: Which layer of the TCP/IP model is responsible for moving data between devices on the same network?
questions.explanation: The Link Layer handles data transfer between devices on the same physical network.

questions.question: What does encapsulation refer to in the context of networking?
options: Adding a protocol header to data
questions.answer: Adding a protocol header to data
questions.explanation: Encapsulation is the process of adding headers and possibly trailers around data to form a packet suitable for transmission.

questions.question: In the OSI model, which layer is responsible for end-to-end communication and error recovery?
questions.explanation: The Transport Layer ensures reliable end-to-end communication, managing data transmission and error recovery.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a part of the TCP/IP protocol stack?
questions.explanation: The Session Layer is part of the OSI model, not the TCP/IP stack, which combines its functionality into the Application Layer.

questions.question: Which protocol is used to translate domain names into IP addresses?
questions.explanation: DNS (Domain Name System) translates human-friendly domain names like www.google.com into IP addresses.

questions.question: What is the main difference between TCP and UDP?
options: TCP is connection-oriented, UDP is connectionless
TCP is faster, UDP is slower
TCP is used for DNS, UDP is used for HTTP
TCP is unreliable, UDP is reliable
questions.answer: TCP is connection-oriented, UDP is connectionless
questions.explanation: TCP provides a reliable connection-oriented service, while UDP is faster but connectionless and does not guarantee delivery.

questions.question: Which layer of the TCP/IP model handles routing of data from source to destination?
questions.explanation: The Network Layer handles routing and forwarding of data packets to ensure they reach their destination across different networks.

questions.question: In the context of TCP/IP, what is a datagram?
options: A packet at the Application Layer
A packet at the Link Layer
A packet at the Network Layer
A packet at the Physical Layer
questions.answer: A packet at the Network Layer
questions.explanation: A datagram is a unit of data at the Network Layer of the TCP/IP protocol stack, typically used in connectionless communications.

questions.question: Which protocol provides reliable data transmission by ensuring error recovery?
questions.explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) provides reliable data transmission by detecting errors and retransmitting lost packets.

questions.question: What is the PDU (Protocol Data Unit) called at the Transport Layer in TCP/IP?
questions.explanation: At the Transport Layer, the PDU is called a segment, which contains the data and transport layer headers.

questions.question: Which of the following is a responsibility of the Physical Layer in the TCP/IP model?
options: Moving individual bits across a network medium
questions.answer: Moving individual bits across a network medium
questions.explanation: The Physical Layer is responsible for transmitting raw bits over a physical communication channel, like a wire or fiber-optic cable.

questions.question: What does the term 'peer-to-peer communication' mean in protocol layering?
options: Communication between devices at the same protocol layer
questions.answer: Communication between devices at the same protocol layer
questions.explanation: Peer-to-peer communication refers to communication between devices at the same layer on the sender and receiver sides.

questions.question: In protocol architecture, what is the main benefit of layering?
questions.explanation: Layering simplifies protocol design by separating tasks into distinct layers, making it easier to troubleshoot and upgrade each part independently.

questions.question: Which of the following protocols is used for email transfer in the Application Layer?
questions.explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is used for sending and receiving email messages over the Internet.

questions.question: Which of the following layers of the OSI model is responsible for establishing, managing, and terminating communication sessions?
questions.explanation: The Session Layer in the OSI model manages the setup, control, and termination of communication sessions between devices.

questions.question: Which TCP/IP layer corresponds to the Data Link Layer in the OSI model?
questions.explanation: The Link Layer in TCP/IP corresponds to both the Data Link and Physical layers of the OSI model.

questions.question: What is the PDU at the Data Link Layer of the OSI model?
questions.explanation: The PDU at the Data Link Layer is called a frame, which includes both data and control information like error checking.

questions.question: Which protocol suite includes the Internet Protocol (IP)?
questions.explanation: The TCP/IP protocol suite includes the Internet Protocol (IP) for routing data across networks.

questions.question: Which protocol is used to transfer files between computers over a network?
questions.explanation: FTP (File Transfer Protocol) is used for transferring files between computers over a network.

questions.question: What is the main responsibility of the physical layer in the TCP/IP model?
options: Transmitting raw bits over the communication medium
questions.answer: Transmitting raw bits over the communication medium
questions.explanation: The physical layer is responsible for transmitting raw bits (0s and 1s) over a physical communication channel like a wire or fiber-optic cable.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of guided transmission media?
questions.explanation: Fiber-optic cables are a type of guided transmission media where data is transmitted using light through a physical medium.

questions.question: What does modulation refer to in the context of analog signals?
options: Varying a signal's properties to represent data
questions.answer: Varying a signal's properties to represent data
questions.explanation: Modulation is the process of varying one or more properties of an analog signal (amplitude, frequency, or phase) to represent digital data.

questions.question: Which encoding scheme represents binary data using two voltage levels?
questions.explanation: Binary encoding uses two voltage levels (typically 0 and 1) to represent digital data in a transmission system.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key characteristic of optical fiber cables?
questions.explanation: Optical fiber cables support high data rates and long-distance data transmission with low signal loss and are immune to electromagnetic interference (EMI).

questions.question: What is the function of a Network Interface Card (NIC)?
options: Connects a device to a network
questions.answer: Connects a device to a network
questions.explanation: A NIC connects a device to a network, enabling it to transmit and receive data over a wired or wireless medium.

questions.question: Which term refers to the weakening of a signal as it travels over a transmission medium?
questions.explanation: Attenuation refers to the gradual weakening of a signal as it travels further from the source along a transmission medium.

questions.question: Which signal modulation technique represents data using different amplitude levels?
questions.explanation: Amplitude modulation (AM) represents binary data using different amplitude levels, where one level represents a binary 1 and another level represents a binary 0.

questions.question: What is Manchester encoding used for?
questions.explanation: Manchester encoding is used for data transmission in Ethernet networks at low speeds (e.g., 10 Mbps).

questions.question: Which wireless frequency band is used by newer Wi-Fi standards such as 802.11ac?
questions.explanation: Newer Wi-Fi standards like 802.11ac and 802.11n operate on the 5 GHz frequency band, providing faster data rates and less interference.

questions.question: Which of the following media is most susceptible to electromagnetic interference (EMI)?
questions.explanation: Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP) cables are more susceptible to electromagnetic interference (EMI) than fiber-optic or coaxial cables.

questions.question: Which transmission medium has the highest resistance to interference and noise?
questions.explanation: Fiber-optic cables are immune to electromagnetic interference and noise, making them highly reliable for data transmission over long distances.

questions.question: What does NEXT (Near-End Crosstalk) refer to in twisted-pair cabling?
options: Signal attenuation due to long distances
Signal coupling between adjacent pairs of wires
questions.answer: Signal coupling between adjacent pairs of wires
questions.explanation: NEXT refers to the signal interference caused by electromagnetic coupling between adjacent pairs of wires within a twisted-pair cable.

questions.question: Which of the following connectors is typically used with UTP cables?
questions.explanation: RJ-45 connectors are commonly used to terminate UTP cables in networking environments, especially for Ethernet connections.

questions.question: Which type of fiber optic cable supports longer distances but uses more expensive laser technology?
questions.explanation: Single-mode fiber uses expensive laser technology but can support much longer distances than multimode fiber.

questions.question: What is the main advantage of fiber-optic cabling over copper cabling?
options: Greater bandwidth and longer distance support
questions.answer: Greater bandwidth and longer distance support
questions.explanation: Fiber-optic cabling supports higher bandwidth and can transmit data over longer distances with lower signal loss compared to copper cables.

questions.question: Which physical medium is commonly used to connect wireless antennas to devices?
questions.explanation: Coaxial cables are commonly used in wireless installations to connect antennas to devices, providing reliable signal transmission.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of single-mode fiber?
options: Has a very small core and supports long-distance communication
questions.answer: Has a very small core and supports long-distance communication
questions.explanation: Single-mode fiber has a small core and uses lasers for long-distance communication, making it ideal for high-speed, long-range applications.

questions.question: What does the term 'attenuation' refer to in signal transmission?
questions.explanation: Attenuation refers to the reduction in signal strength as it travels further from the source over a transmission medium.

questions.question: Which transmission medium is completely immune to electromagnetic interference (EMI)?
questions.explanation: Fiber-optic cables use light to transmit data and are completely immune to electromagnetic interference (EMI) and radio frequency interference (RFI).

questions.question: What is the main purpose of the Ethernet technology in a Local Area Network (LAN)?
options: Enable wired data transmission within a LAN
questions.answer: Enable wired data transmission within a LAN
questions.explanation: Ethernet is a dominant LAN technology that allows wired data transmission within a local area network.

questions.question: Which protocol is responsible for managing access to the network medium in Ethernet?
questions.explanation: Ethernet uses CSMA/CD (Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection) to manage access to the shared network medium and prevent data collisions.

questions.question: What is a MAC address used for in a network?
options: To uniquely identify a device on a network
To store the IP address of a device
To provide wireless access to a device
questions.answer: To uniquely identify a device on a network
questions.explanation: A MAC address is a 48-bit physical address that uniquely identifies a device on the network.

questions.question: What happens when a collision is detected in an Ethernet network using CSMA/CD?
options: The packet is dropped and retransmission is attempted after a random backoff time
The packet is forwarded to the destination
questions.answer: The packet is dropped and retransmission is attempted after a random backoff time
questions.explanation: When a collision is detected, CSMA/CD aborts the transmission and reschedules it after a random backoff period to minimize the chance of future collisions.

questions.question: Which of the following devices operates at the Link Layer and is responsible for forwarding Ethernet frames?
questions.explanation: A switch is a Link Layer device that forwards Ethernet frames based on the MAC addresses of the devices connected to it.

questions.question: Which component in a network enables multiple devices to transmit data simultaneously without causing collisions?
questions.explanation: An Ethernet switch manages multiple simultaneous transmissions by creating separate collision domains for each connection.

questions.question: What is the primary function of VLANs (Virtual Local Area Networks)?
options: To increase the speed of Ethernet networks
To isolate network traffic within a single broadcast domain
questions.answer: To isolate network traffic within a single broadcast domain
questions.explanation: VLANs are used to create virtual broadcast domains within a network, isolating traffic between different groups of devices for security and efficiency.

questions.question: Which protocol standard defines wireless LANs (WLANs)?
questions.explanation: The IEEE 802.11 standard defines wireless LANs, commonly known as Wi-Fi.

questions.question: What is the role of the preamble in an Ethernet frame?
options: To synchronize the sender and receiver clocks
questions.answer: To synchronize the sender and receiver clocks
questions.explanation: The preamble is a sequence of bits used to synchronize the sender and receiver clocks before the transmission of data begins.

questions.question: What type of addressing is used at the Link Layer?
questions.explanation: The Link Layer uses MAC (Media Access Control) addressing to uniquely identify devices on a network.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about an Ethernet switch?
options: It operates at the network layer
It floods all incoming traffic to every port
It forwards frames based on MAC addresses
It is responsible for routing packets across networks
questions.answer: It forwards frames based on MAC addresses
questions.explanation: An Ethernet switch forwards frames to the correct destination by using the MAC addresses of the devices connected to it.

questions.question: What is the primary reason for using VLANs in a network?
options: To reduce the cost of hardware
questions.explanation: VLANs are used to segment a network into multiple broadcast domains, which helps isolate traffic and improve security.

questions.question: Which term refers to the part of the network where multiple devices share the same medium and can collide with each other's transmissions?
questions.explanation: A collision domain is a part of the network where multiple devices share the same medium, leading to potential data collisions.

questions.question: What is the function of CSMA/CA in a wireless LAN?
questions.explanation: CSMA/CA (Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Avoidance) is used in wireless networks to avoid collisions by reserving the channel before transmission.

questions.question: What does a wireless access point (AP) do in a WLAN?
options: Connects wireless devices to the wired network
Assigns IP addresses to wireless devices
Encrypts data on the wireless network
questions.answer: Connects wireless devices to the wired network
questions.explanation: A wireless access point (AP) connects wireless devices to a wired network, allowing communication between wireless clients and the network.

questions.question: Which type of Ethernet frame format includes a VLAN tag?
questions.explanation: The 802.1Q frame format includes a VLAN tag to support VLAN functionality within Ethernet networks.

questions.question: Which device operates at the link layer and can filter and forward Ethernet frames based on MAC addresses?
questions.explanation: A switch operates at the Link Layer and filters and forwards frames based on the MAC addresses of the devices connected to it.

questions.question: What is the benefit of using full-duplex mode in Ethernet communication?
options: It allows simultaneous data transmission and reception
It reduces collision rates in wireless networks
questions.answer: It allows simultaneous data transmission and reception
questions.explanation: Full-duplex mode allows devices to transmit and receive data simultaneously, improving the efficiency of Ethernet communication.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a VLAN trunk port?
options: To carry frames between different VLANs
To create multiple VLANs on a single switch
To connect multiple switches carrying VLAN traffic
questions.answer: To connect multiple switches carrying VLAN traffic
questions.explanation: A VLAN trunk port carries VLAN traffic between multiple switches, allowing VLANs to span across different switches.

questions.question: Which of the following is used to avoid collisions in a wireless network?
questions.explanation: Wireless networks use CSMA/CA (Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Avoidance) to avoid collisions by reserving the channel before transmission.

questions.question: What is the main function of the network layer in the OSI model?
questions.explanation: The network layer is responsible for routing packets from the source to the destination and forwarding them through intermediate routers.

questions.question: What does the Time to Live (TTL) field in an IP datagram represent?
options: The number of seconds a packet can exist
The number of hops a packet can take
The time it takes for a packet to be delivered
questions.answer: The number of hops a packet can take
questions.explanation: TTL limits the number of hops a packet can take before being discarded to prevent it from looping indefinitely in the network.

questions.question: Which protocol is used for error reporting and signaling in IP networks?
questions.explanation: ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol) is used to send error messages and operational information about network conditions.

questions.question: What is a subnet?
options: A smaller network within a larger network
questions.answer: A smaller network within a larger network
questions.explanation: A subnet is a segment of a network that shares a common network ID and can communicate without passing through a router.

questions.question: Which of the following IP addresses belongs to a Class A network?
questions.explanation: Class A networks have IP addresses that range from 1.0.0.0 to 126.0.0.0, and 10.0.0.1 falls within this range.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of hosts that can be supported in a Class C network?
questions.explanation: In a Class C network, 8 bits are reserved for the host portion, allowing 2^8 - 2 = 254 usable host addresses.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Network Address Translation (NAT)?
options: To convert private IP addresses into public IP addresses
To encrypt data for secure transmission
To route data between different subnets
questions.answer: To convert private IP addresses into public IP addresses
questions.explanation: NAT is used to map private IP addresses to a public IP address, enabling devices in a local network to access external networks such as the Internet.

questions.question: What is a public IP address?
options: An address used for private networks
An address that is visible and routable on the Internet
An address reserved for local communication
An address used for NAT translation
questions.answer: An address that is visible and routable on the Internet
questions.explanation: Public IP addresses are globally unique and used for devices that need to communicate over the Internet.

questions.question: Which of the following is a reserved private IP address range?
questions.explanation: The IP range 192.168.0.0/16 is reserved for private network use and cannot be routed on the public Internet.

questions.question: What does the fragmentation of an IP datagram involve?
options: Combining smaller packets into a larger one
Splitting a large datagram into smaller fragments
Dropping packets that exceed the MTU
questions.answer: Splitting a large datagram into smaller fragments
questions.explanation: Fragmentation occurs when a large IP datagram exceeds the MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit) of the underlying network and is split into smaller fragments for transmission.

questions.question: What is the function of the subnet mask?
options: To determine the class of an IP address
To identify the network and host portions of an IP address
questions.answer: To identify the network and host portions of an IP address
questions.explanation: The subnet mask helps determine which part of an IP address is the network ID and which part is the host ID.

questions.question: Which field in an IP datagram indicates the total length of the datagram?
questions.explanation: The Total Length field in the IP header specifies the total length of the datagram, including both the header and data.

questions.question: Which of the following IP addresses is used for loopback testing?
questions.explanation: The IP address 127.0.0.1 is reserved for loopback testing, allowing a host to communicate with itself.

questions.question: What is Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) used for?
options: Assigning IP addresses in fixed classes
Dividing IP address space into subnets
questions.answer: Dividing IP address space into subnets
questions.explanation: CIDR allows the flexible allocation of IP addresses by removing the fixed class-based allocation and using variable-length subnet masks.

questions.question: What is the maximum size of an IP datagram?
questions.explanation: The maximum size of an IP datagram is 65,535 bytes (64 KB), as determined by the 16-bit Total Length field in the IP header.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the identification field in an IP datagram?
options: To identify the type of service
To uniquely identify fragments of a datagram
To check for errors in transmission
questions.answer: To uniquely identify fragments of a datagram
questions.explanation: The identification field is used to uniquely identify fragments that belong to the same datagram, so they can be reassembled correctly at the destination.

questions.question: What is the primary reason for subnetting a network?
options: To increase IP address usage efficiency
questions.answer: To increase IP address usage efficiency
questions.explanation: Subnetting allows for more efficient use of IP address space by dividing a larger network into smaller, more manageable subnetworks.

questions.question: Which part of an IP address identifies the specific host on a network?
questions.explanation: The Host ID is the portion of the IP address that uniquely identifies a device on a network, while the Network ID identifies the network.

questions.question: What is the function of the Don't Fragment (DF) bit in the IP header?
questions.explanation: The DF bit in the IP header instructs routers not to fragment the datagram, even if it exceeds the MTU of the underlying network.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the TTL field in the IP header?
options: To prevent datagrams from looping indefinitely
To measure the time taken to transmit a packet
To specify the length of the IP header
questions.answer: To prevent datagrams from looping indefinitely
questions.explanation: TTL is a mechanism to limit the lifetime of a packet in the network by reducing its value at each hop, preventing it from looping indefinitely.

quizzes.title: Data Communication and Networking - Guess Paper 1

questions.question: What is the purpose of a protocol in data communication?
Which topology connects all devices to a central hub?
What is the role of the network layer in the OSI model?
What does CSMA/CD stand for?
options: Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection
Code Sense Multiple Access with Controlled Division
Carrier Sense Mode Access with Controlled Division
Collision Sense Multiple Access with Delay
questions.answer: Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection

questions.question: Which of the following addresses is used for broadcast in IPv4?
Which of the following is a layer 2 (Link Layer) protocol?
What is the main function of the transport layer in the OSI model?
Which protocol is responsible for routing IP datagrams?
What is the main characteristic of a full-duplex communication system?
options: Data can flow in both directions simultaneously
Data is broadcast to all devices
Data is transmitted and received in time slots
questions.answer: Data can flow in both directions simultaneously

questions.question: Which field in an IP datagram determines how many routers the packet can pass through?

quizzes.title: Data Communication and Networking - Guess Paper 2

questions.question: What does the term 'subnetting' refer to in networking?
options: Dividing a network into smaller networks
questions.answer: Dividing a network into smaller networks

questions.question: What is the function of Network Address Translation (NAT)?
options: To convert private IP addresses to public addresses
questions.answer: To convert private IP addresses to public addresses

questions.question: Which of the following protocols operates at the transport layer of the OSI model?
What is the purpose of VLANs in networking?
options: To isolate network traffic into broadcast domains
To reduce latency in wireless networks
questions.answer: To isolate network traffic into broadcast domains

questions.question: Which of the following is a physical transmission medium?
What is the maximum size of an IPv4 datagram?
Which term describes the process of breaking a large IP datagram into smaller fragments?
Which of the following IP addresses is reserved for private networks?
What is the purpose of the preamble in an Ethernet frame?
What does ICMP stand for?

quizzes.title: Data Communication and Networking - Guess Paper 3

questions.question: Which layer in the OSI model is responsible for data encapsulation into frames?
What is a MAC address used for?
options: Uniquely identifying devices on a network
questions.answer: Uniquely identifying devices on a network

questions.question: What is the primary function of an Ethernet switch?
options: To forward frames based on MAC addresses
questions.answer: To forward frames based on MAC addresses

questions.question: Which network topology connects all devices to a common shared medium?
What does the term 'broadcast domain' refer to?
options: A network segment where all devices receive the same broadcast traffic
A network segment that uses encryption
A domain used for DNS routing
questions.answer: A network segment where all devices receive the same broadcast traffic

questions.question: Which field in an IP datagram specifies the protocol used by the upper layers?
Which of the following is true about IPv4 addresses?
options: They are reserved for private networks
They are used only in the US

questions.question: Which of the following protocols is connectionless?
What is the function of a router in a network?
options: To forward data between different networks
To broadcast data to all devices
questions.answer: To forward data between different networks

questions.question: Which protocol is used for file transfer over the Internet?
